title: Kylie Minogue will take fiancé Joshua Sasse's surname when they marry: "It's a great stage name"
text:

Kylie Minogue has said she WILL take fiancé Joshua Sasse’s surname when they marry, but no plans for a trip down the aisle have been drawn up yet. 
The I Should Be So Lucky singer and actress, 48, is enjoying her engagement to Joshua , 29, whom she’s been with for the last 18 months. 
In a new interview with You magazine, she says the couple aren’t rushing wedding plans – but she has already decided to change her name. Kylie says she'll take Joshua's surname (Photo: Getty) 
“Sasse is a great name. Kylie Sasse is a great name. It’s a great stage name. Kylie Minogue has never exactly tripped off the tongue. I’ll definitely be taking Sasse but there will be Minogue in there somewhere. Taking a different name makes a statement.” 
Kylie and Joshua became engaged in February 2016: actor Josh proposed to her with a princess-cut diamond ring that was made in 1908. 
“For me, it’s perfect,” said Kylie. “I’m not the sort of girl who would wear a solitaire. He got exactly the right ring for me. I love it. I love wearing it and what it represents.” (Photo: FameFlynet.uk.com) Check out that beautiful ring! (Photo: Getty Images) 
Kylie also told the magazine that when she thinks about Josh, a famous line from Richard Curtis’ classic movie Notting Hill always comes to mind. 
It’s the part when Julia Roberts’ superstar character pledges her love to Hugh Grant’s bookseller, telling him her fame doesn’t make a difference. 
“When I look into Josh’s eyes, he is all I see and that makes me very happy,” said Kylie. “There’s a line in the movie Notting Hill that I always think of, when Julia Roberts is talking to High Grant, and she says, ‘I’m just a girl, standing in front of a boy, asking him to love her.’ 
“For me, it’s that simple.” Kylie said she adores her engagement ring (Photo: WireImage) 
Kylie and Joshua have previously said they wouldn't marry until same sex couples in her native Australia were granted the same rights as they have in Britain. 
Joshua told Australia's Network Seven about the couple's decision last year after Sunrise presenters asked him if they would wed in Melbourne. 
The actor said: "There are chances of a Melbourne wedding but me and Kylie have talked about it and we are not comfortable getting married until this law has passed." At last year's Brit Awards together (Photo: Reuters) 
"That is something that we've talked about and decided on. Why should we? Why is it fair? Why are we more important than anyone else? It's not right and something's got to be done about it." 
"I simply can't fathom on any level, whether it's moral, religious or anything, that I have the right to get married and to marry the person I love and that somebody else doesn't just because of their sexual orientation." 
Dolly Parton, Scissor Sisters' frontman Jake Shears - who is a good friend of Kylie's - and actress Margot Robbie are among the names who have campaigned to change the law in Australia. Like us on Facebook
